section.title: Requirements
section.para: The following software is needed to compile and run the web application. Servlet containers other than Jetty may work, but this is untested, and the configuration instructions may be Jetty-specific.

listitem.para: Java Development Kit, at least version 6.
Jetty, the web server (only version 6.x has been tested; newer versions might or might not work).
Maven 3, which is the build system for the web application (Maven 2 might still work).

It is highly recommended that the HTML DTDs are installed locally (e.g. in Ubuntu this is in the w3c-dtd-html package). Otherwise, these will be fetched from the internet on each build, which can be very slow.

The Ubuntu installation of the DTD also has some flaws that prevent them from working properly (see this bug). In short, you need to look for catalog.xml files in /usr/share/xml/xhtml and /usr/share/xml/entities/xhtml and replace http://globaltranscorp.org/oasis/catalog/xml/tr9401.dtd in the header with file:////usr/share/xml/schema/xml-core/tr9401.dtd.

section.para: Maven will also download assorted Java packages the first time it is run, so an internet connection will be required. After the first time it should be possible to build while offline.

section.para: All building is done from the webapp directory. Build the web application by running
This will produce target/abacuscm-1.0-SNAPSHOT.war, and will also place a copy in $HOME/.m2/repository/abacuscm/abacuscm/1.0-SNAPSHOT/.

section.title: Configuration
section.para: The first thing you will need to do is configure a Jetty server to start up. The process for doing this will vary between platforms, but on Ubuntu you will most likely need to edit /etc/default/jetty to change NO_START to zero, and possibly to edit other parameters there as well.
Note that getting Jetty to run on a standard HTTP port (80) is non-trivial; it is probably best to get all the setup done before trying to switch it over to a standard port.
I have also found that sometimes Jetty will only listen on IPv6. I have worked around this by adding JAVA_OPTIONS="-Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true" to /etc/default/jetty.

You should also ensure that Jetty is set up for hot deployment from a directory like /etc/jetty/contexts; this might require uncommenting some configuration options in /etc/jetty/jetty.xml, but again, this is platform-specific.

section.title: Creating the keystore
section.para: When the web application (on the web server side) connects to the abacus server, it needs to be able to verify the certificate presented by the abacus server. For this, it needs the certificate for the CA used to sign that certificate (generated in ; it also needs to be imported into a Java keystore.
This can be done as follows:

screen.computeroutput: Enter keystore password: Re-enter new password: Certificate was added to keystore

section.para: Since the keystore contains only a certificate and no keys, the password does not need to be secure (and probably should not be a secure password used elsewhere, since it will be stored in plain text in a configuration file).
Refer to for information about how to point the web application at this new keystore.

section.title: Configuring the context
section.para: In the directory configured for hot context deployment (e.g., /etc/jetty/contexts, create an XML file with the following contents (the filename is arbitrary; we use abacuscm.xml):
section.programlisting: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <!DOCTYPE Configure PUBLIC "-//Mort Bay Consulting//DTD Configure//EN" "http://jetty.mortbay.org/configure.dtd"> <Configure class="org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebAppContext"> <Set name="contextPath">/contextPath</Set> <Set name="war">/path/to/war</Set> <Set name="overrideDescriptor"><SystemProperty name="jetty.home" default="." />/etc/abacuscm-secret-web.xml</Set> </Configure>
section.para: The contextPath is the path within the server URL at which clients will access the web application, while /path/to/war is the path to the .war file created by the build. Note that this file will need to be accessible to Jetty, in which case it may be necessary to copy it from where it was built to a deployment area.

note.para: Although this is a hot deployment, only this XML configuration file is scanned for changes. If you change the .war file, you will need to touch this file (or restart Jetty) to trigger an update.

section.para: The overrideDescriptor can be set to any path, which points to a file containing extra configuration data specific to this deployment. It should contain the following:
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <web-app xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee/web-app_2_5.xsd" version="2.5">
<servlet> <servlet-name>initializer</servlet-name> <init-param> <param-name>abacusHost</param-name> <param-value>host name</param-value> </init-param> <init-param> <param-name>abacusPort</param-name> <param-value>port number</param-value> </init-param> <init-param> <param-name>trustStoreURL</param-name> <param-value>URL</param-value> </init-param> <init-param> <param-name>trustStorePassword</param-name> <param-value>password</param-value> </init-param> </servlet> </web-app>
section.para: The abacusHost and abacusPort parameters are optional, and default to localhost and 7368 respectively.
The trustStoreURL must be the URL of the keystore configured in . If the file is on the local machine, it must use a file:// URL rather than a filename.

section.title: Choosing the right connector
section.para: Depending on the configuration files provided by your platform, Jetty may be using a sub-optimal method to handle large numbers of connections. You should use SelectChannelConnector or SSLSelectChannelConnector to avoid creating a separate thread per connection. See the Jetty documentation for more information.

section.title: Running Jetty on standard ports
section.para: Without running jetty as root, seriously not recommended, it's (to the best of the this Author's knowledge) not possible to run jetty or even Tomcat on standard ports.

As a workaround we recommend using iptables (netfilter) to redirect the standard ports to the jetty ports. Assuming you don't have any NAT rules already set up, but do have iptables installed, this can be achieved with the following commands:
section.programlisting: iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 443 -j REDIRECT \ --to-ports 8443 iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT \ --to-ports 8080
